text: I slowly reached for my short sword—only to hear the faint metallic clang as the scabbard brushed against my belt.
The drunkard snapped his head around, bloodshot eyes glaring straight at me.
His fury ignited at once; his fist slammed onto the table, sending liquor splashing everywhere.
I instinctively stepped back. My hand hadn’t even gripped the hilt fully, yet the air was already thick with tension.
Just as he took a step forward, a sharp sound cut through the air—not wind, but the song of a sword.
Alicia was already moving. Her cloak swept past the fire, and a flash of silver split the air.
No one saw what she did—only that, in the next instant, the drunkard was pinned to the floor, his face buried in his own spilled drink.
I stared at her in shock. At that moment, I realized—I never needed to draw my sword at all.
She sheathed her blade. The firelight flickered across the cracked pattern on its edge.
“You have quite the way of intimidating people.”
“Depends on who I’m dealing with,” I replied with a faint smile, lowering the sword I hadn’t drawn.
